title: Worley's biggest shareholder disappointed with board
text:
Street Talk revealed Worley had provided the Foreign Investment Review Board with a document titled, Worley and the National Interest.

Worley confirmed on Wednesday that it had provided information about its operations as part of confidential FIRB processes in the context of possible creeping acquisitions by Dar.

Worley said it had engaged with Dar regarding additional share acquisitions, a Dar request for board representation and for a comprehensive business co-operation agreement.

The Worley board believes it is not in shareholders’ interests for Dar to further increase its stake by creeping acquisitions or for Worley to enter into a business co-operation agreement with Dar.

“In coming to this view, the Worley board has considered the impact of these matters on stakeholders who are critical to its business, including shareholders, customers, governments, our people and partners,” Worley said.

Dar said it had spoken with Worley to “seek appropriate board representation” reflecting its position as the biggest shareholder and about a formal business co-operation agreement.

“Since becoming a substantial shareholder in Worley, Dar Group and Worley have commenced working collaboratively on several individual projects which have delivered benefits for both groups,” a Dar spokesman said.

“Therefore, Dar Group is disappointed that the Worley Board believes it is not in shareholders’ interests for Worley to enter into a comprehensive business cooperation agreement with Dar Group.

Advertisement

“Dar Group continues to believe that deepening the collaboration between the two companies has the potential to create value for both sets of shareholders.”

Worley is a global provider of engineering, project and asset services in the energy, chemicals and resources sectors while Dar operates in 59 countries and employs about 19,000 people.

The Worley and the National Interest document obtained by Street Talk said Worley was a globally significant Australian company.

It said the board had a clear understanding that Dar was seeking control of Worley – a matter that had been disclosed in meetings between the companies' respective chairmen.

"At these meetings, Dar Group has stated its intention to continue to increase its shareholding to seek governance control by appointing two nominees, including a Dar Group executive, to the Worley board, and to seek operational control through joint business initiatives," the document said.

Dar has been in close contact with FIRB since it bought an initial 13 per cent stake in the company in February 2017, which followed Worley's decision to reject an unsolicited $2.9 billion takeover offer from Dar.

Worley’s $4.6 billion acquisition of the Jacobs Engineering Group's energy, resources and chemicals business, completed earlier this year, was seen in part as a defensive move to put the company beyond Dar’s reach.

With annual revenues doubling to more than $9 billion after buying Jacobs, Worley was regarded as too big for Dar, which has annual revenues of about $US2.5 billion, to take out on its own.

National interest factors typically considered by FIRB include competition, other Australian Government policies, the impact on the economy and the community, national security and the investor's character.
description: Dar Group refuses to back down on push for co-operation agreement with $8.2 billion engineering giant.
